Section 1 c INDIVIDUAL MEMBERS so elected to the NAEB as prescribed by the
Constitution shall have no voting power and they cannot be elected to any
constituted office of this association. They may, however, be extended the
privilege of the floor at regularly stated conventions of the association.
Make these changes and you can carry the educational T? stations along with us. BUT
I am inalterably opposed to changing those portions of Article III, Section 1 a of
the By-Laws which reads as follows: "Shall be eligible for active membership in the
association to the extent of one membership for each institution, irrespective of the
number of stations operated by the member"....and....."Each active member shall be
entitled to one vote and shall be entitled to participate in all affairs of the
association"•
Here the emphasis is on INSTITUTIONAL MEMBERSHIP and not on how many radio and TV
stations may be operated by the institution. When a great number of us added FM
station to our operations, no one got any more votes.
Furthermore, I am of the opinion that we should hold to the FCCfs definition of an
educational TV station. I well remember the hassel v/e had over some of the radio
operations that went commercial but still wanted to be in NAEB. A commercial TV
station is commercial whether it’s operated for non-profit or not. To depart from
the basic principles which have been established over the years by blood, sweat and
tears would be making a grave mistake.
The fact that only one vote is allowed an institution, regardless of how many broad¬
cast stations they may operate, does not preclude the fact that the institution and
its broadcasting personnel can be very active in the affairs of NAEB, Nor does it
keep any institution from sending as many representatives to national meetings as
the old pocketbook will allow. And these people can be appointed to committees as
per the Constitution and By-Laws and can have a vote in the business of these
committees.
In this connection, I am in favor of overhauling our whole concept of NAEB which is
geared too much to the horse and buggy days of the association. With the advent of
the School Broadcast station and more lately the educational TV station, it seems
logical there should be spheres of activity incorporated into the thinking and
work of NAEB:
RADIO
1. The general educational radio operation (either AM or FM) with perhaps
greater interest on general adult programming but may include on a secondary
level in-school broadcasts.
2. The school broadcast stations (mostly FM) which serve the classrooms of the
system which sponsors the station. Some programs of general interest but in
the main the emphasis is on the school room audience,
3. The production center which uses facilities not its own. No problems of
station operation. Emphasis wholly on production either for general audience
or school room.
TELEVISION
The educational television operation may eventually have to be divided very
much as radio. Right now two divisions will suffice:
1. Educational television station.
2. Television production center.
